newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico slaps tariffs on U.S. ammonium sulphate.
newsitem.headline: Mexico slaps tariffs on U.S. ammonium sulphate.

text.p: Mexico has placed variable tariffs on imports from the United States of ammonium sulphate for alleged dumping of the product, the government's Official Gazettee published Wednesday.
The gazette said the tariffs, whose levels depend on the import price, are the result of a preliminary investigation into imports of the product from the United States.
The government was petitioned by Mexican fertilizer producers to look into alleged dumping of imports at prices below production cost or at prices below sales in the United States.
The gazette said the tariffs applied to ammonium sulphate imported from the U.S., irrespective of where it was originally produced.

"Imports of ammonium sulphate...coming from the United States, independent of where they were produced, whose prices are below the average normal price of $97.18 per tonne, will pay a compensatory tariff that is the difference between the export price of the goods and the average normal price," the gazette said.
It added that export price will be considered the "ex-works" price of the ammonium sulphate.
"The amounts of the compensatory tariffs, determined by the above formula, will not be above the ceiling of 57.91 percent," the government's gazette added.
It added that U.S. imports of ammonium sulphate which are at the average normal value, or above it, will not be subject to import duties.
Mexican fertilizer companies Agrogen SA, Fertilizantes Guadalajara SA and Fertirey SA first requested the anti-dumping investigation in June 1995.
U.S. exporters named in the dumping suit are Allied Signal Inc, BASF Corp, a U.S. subsidiary of BASF AG, DBA Chemicals Entreprises, DSM Chemicals North America Inc and Zipp Enterprises.
